question: I say, my friend, do you know a fellow by the name of Longfellow Deeds?
answer: Deeds?

question: Yes.
answer: Yes, sir. Yes, indeedy. Everyone knows Deeds.

question: We'd like to get in touch with him. It's very important.
answer: Who's that?

question: Deeds! Who do you think I'm talking about?
answer: Oh, yes - Deeds. Fine fellow. Very democratic. You won't have no trouble at all. Talk to anybody.

question: No, we won't! The next time that jumping jack comes out, I'll straddle him while you ask him your questions.
answer: Morning, neighbors.

question: Remember us? We're the fellows who were here a minute ago.
answer: Oh, yes. Yes, indeedy. I never forget a face.

question: Listen, Pop, we've come all the way from New York to look up a fellow by the name of Deeds. It's important - very important! Then please pretend, for just one fleeting moment, that I'm asking. Where does he reside?
answer: Who?

question: Come in, please. Come in. Can I get you a cup of tea?
answer: No, thanks.

question: Sit down. Sure I couldn't get you a glass of lemonade or something?
answer: That's very kind of you. Are you related to him?

question: No, I'm his housekeeper.
answer: Well, we'd like to find out something about him. What does he do for a living?

question: All right.
answer: Mr. Deeds, are you the son of Dr. Joseph and Mary Deeds?

question: Yes.
answer: Are your parents living?

question: Why, no.
answer: Mr. Deeds, does the name of Martin W. Semple mean anything to you?

question: Not much. He's an uncle of mine, I think. I never saw him, but my mother's name was Semple, you know.
answer: Well, he passed on. He was killed in a motor accident in Italy.

question: He was? Gee, that's too bad. If there's anything I can do to
answer: I have good news for you, sir. Mr. Semple left a large fortune when he died. He left it all to you, Mr. Deeds. Deducting the taxes, it amounts to something in the neighborhood of $20,000,000.

question: Cedar, Cedar, Cedar and Budington. Funny, I can't think of a rhyme for Budington.
answer: Why should you?

question: Well, whenever I run across a funny name, I always like to poke around for a rhyme. Don't you?
answer: Nah.

question: I've got one for Cobb "There once was a man named Cobb,
answer: Sounds like a two weeks' notice to me.

question: Huh?
answer: I've gotten the 'sackaroo' in many ways - but never in rhyme.

question: Oh, I don't mean that. I'm sure I'm going to need your help.
answer: Oh, that's different if it's just poetry.

question: Who - me? No.
answer: No, he's too fussy for that. That's what's the matter with him. There are lots of nice girls right here in Mandrake Falls who're dying to be married

question: Don't pay any attention to her.
answer: He's got a lot of foolish notions - about saving a lady in distress.

question: Goodbye, Mrs. Meredith! Goodbye, Jim! Bye, Buddy! Goodbye, everybody!
answer: Will you have a cigar?

question: No, thank you. Oh, I wasn't worried about that.
answer: No?

question: He's been here three days, and what have you numbskulls brought in! Any halfwit novice could have done better! Am I talking too loud? Or annoying anybody? Cobb, Cobb! Never mind about Cobb. Use what little brains you've got! Find out something yourselves, you imbecilic stupes! Now get out of here before I really tell you what I think of you. Come on, get out! You too! Thought I could depend on you, but you're getting as bad as the rest of them. What's gotten into you, Babe? I remember the time when you'd blast this town wide open before you'd let Cobb get away with a thing like this.
answer: Oh, he's not getting away with anything. Can I have a month's vacation?

question: With pay!
answer: With pay!

question: It's the first time I ever had a suit made on purpose.
answer: It's merely a suggestion. I don't wish to press the point, Mr. Deeds, but if you'll give me your Power of Attorney we'll take care of everything. It'll save you a lot of petty annoyances. Every shark in town will be trying to sell you something.

question: Oh, yes, there've been a lot of them around here already. Strangest kind of people. Salesmen - politicians - moochers - all want something. I haven't had a minute to myself. Haven't seen Grant's Tomb yet.
answer: Well, you see, your uncle didn't bother with that sort of thing. He left everything to us. He traveled most of the time, and enjoyed himself. You should do the same thing, Mr. Deeds.

question: Besides wanting to be my lawyer, you also want to handle my investments too?
answer: Yes. That is to say

question: Thanks
answer: Jim Mason? Oh, yeah. Yeah. No, I didn't send it. I've got it written out, though. Here it is.

question: Fine. Send it right away. I don't want him to fire Arthur.
answer: Oh, sure. Sure. We don't want to fire Arthur.

question: He was the last baby my father delivered, Arthur was.
answer: I think you ought to give this matter some thought, Mr. Deeds.

question: Huh?
answer: I mean, about the Power of Attorney.

question: Well, don't let him in.
answer: Why not? Who is he?

question: A lawyer representing some woman with a claim against the estate.
answer: Well, if he has a claim, we'd better see him.

question: He's capable of causing you a lot of trouble, Mr. Deeds.
answer: How can he make any trouble for me? I haven't done anything.

question: You wouldn't dare go into court with a case like this - and you know it! I leave it to you, Mr. Deeds. Can you conceive of any court not being in sympathy with any woman who gave up the best years of her life for an old man like your uncle?
answer: What kind of wife did you say she was?

question: Common-law wife. On top of that, there's a child.
answer: A child? My uncle's?

question: Yes, sir.
answer: That's awful. The poor woman should be taken care of immediately. If she was his wife, she should have all the money. That's only fair. I don't want a penny of it.

question: From what I'm led to believe, the young man's quite childish. I don't think we'll have any difficulty in getting him to put up the entire amount. After all, it's only a matter of $180,000. Good. Now, gentlemen, the first order of business will be the election of a new Chairman of the Board.
answer: Second.

question: All those in favor . . . Carried. Right here, Mr. Deeds. Now, the next order of business is the reading of the Secretary's minutes .
answer: Move we dispense with it.

question: All in favor? I think they can be dispensed with. We're ready now for the reading of the Treasurer's report.
answer: Move we dispense with it.

question: All in favor? Quite right! Now, gentlemen, the next business will be
answer: Wait a minute. What does the Chairman do?

question: Why, the Chairman presides at the meetings.
answer: That's what I thought. If you don't mind, I'm rather interested in the Treasurer's report. I'd like to hear it. A deficit! You mean we've lost that much?

question: You see, Mr. Deeds, the opera is not conducted for profit.
answer: It isn't? What is it conducted for?

question: Why, it's an artistic institution
answer: We own an opera house, don't we?

question: And it doesn't pay?
answer: That's impossible. The opera has never paid. The wrong kind! There isn't any wrong or right kind. Opera is opera!

question: I guess it is. But I personally wouldn't care to be head of a business that kept losing money. That wouldn't be common sense. Incidentally, where is the $180,000 coming from?
answer: Well, we were rather expecting it to come from you.

question: Me?!
answer: Naturally.

question: Excuse me, gentlemen, there's nothing natural about that . Hey, a fire engine! Now, where were we?
answer: You see, Mr. Deeds, the opera is not conducted like any ordinary business.

question: Why not?
answer: Because it just isn't a business, that's all!

question: Sorry to keep you waiting so long. Those opera people are funny. They wanted me to put up $180,000.
answer: What about it, Mr. Deeds?

question: Why, I turned them down, naturally.
answer: No, I mean - about my client.

question: Oh - we'll have to do something about the common wife.
answer: Tails tonight, sir?

question: What - tails?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Goodbye.
answer: Of course, we don't want to appear greedy, Mr. Deeds.

question: Huh?
answer: I say we don't want to appear greedy.

question: I'll do no such thing
answer: That's right. Don't you go to his office. There's only one place you're going, and that's out the door.

question: You're making a mistake, Mr. Deeds.
answer: Oh no, I'm not. I don't like your face. Besides, there's something fishy about a person who would settle for a million dollars when they can get seven million. I'm surprised that Mr. Cedar, who's supposed to be a smart man, couldn't see through that.

question: Now wait a minute, buddy
answer: There's one nice thing about being rich - you ring a bell and things happen. When the servant comes in, Mr. Hallor, I'm going to ask him to show you to the door. Many people don't know where it is.

question: No use in getting tough. That'll get you nowhere, Mr. Deeds.
answer: Will you show Mr. Hallor to the front door?

question: Even his hands are oily.
answer: Well, how about tonight? What would you like in the way of entertainment?

question: Entertainment?
answer: Your uncle had a weakness for dark ones, tall and stately. How would you like yours? Dark or fair, tall or short, fat or thin, tough or tender?

question: What're you talking about?
answer: Women! Ever heard of 'em?

question: Oh.
answer: Name your poison and I'll supply it.

question: Some other time, Cobb. Some other time.
answer: Okay, you're the boss.

question: He talks about women as if they were cattle.
answer: Every man to his taste, sir.

question: Tell me, Walter, are all those stories I hear about my uncle true?
answer: Well, sir, he sometimes had as many as twenty in the house at the same time.

question: Twenty! What did he do with them?
answer: That was something I was never able to find out, sir.

question: Why yes. Isn't that all right?
answer: No. Don't ever want to go out without telling us.

question: Who are you? Oh, yeah.
answer: Yeah, Mr. Cobb said stick to your tail no matter what.

question: You fainted. Can I help you?
answer: No, thank you. I'll be all right.

question: Look, this is my house. I'd like to
answer: Oh, no, really - I'll be all right.

question: What happened?
answer: Well, I guess I walked too much. I've been looking for a job all day. I found one, too. I start tomorrow.

question: Feel better now?
answer: Mmm, it tastes so good. Mr. Deeds, I don't know how I can ever thank you.

question: Tell me more about yourself.
answer: Well, I guess I've told you almost everything there is to tell. My folks live in a small town near Hartford. I'm down here alone trying to make a living.

question: You were a lady in distress, weren't you? Oh - uh - nothing. Waiter! Has anybody come in yet?
answer: Huh? On, no. Nobody important.

question: Be sure and point 'em out to me, won't you?
answer: Uh-huh.

question: I'm a writer myself, you know.
answer: Uh-huh.

question: I write poetry.
answer: Uh-huh.

question: You wouldn't have one in your pocket, would you, Mr. Deeds? No, a postcard - with one of your poems on it.
answer: You mean to tell me you don't carry a pocketful around with you?

question: Too bad! I was hoping you'd autograph one for me.
answer: I was too. Wait a minute, boys. Perhaps Mr. Deeds would recite one for us.

question: That's a very good idea. Nothing like a poet reciting his own stuff.
answer: Exactly! Give us one that wrings the great American heart. Look, he's temperamental.

question: That's all right. I got it off my chest.
answer: The difference between them and me is I know when I've been a skunk. You take me to the nearest news-stand and I'll eat a pack of your postcards raw. Raw! Oh, what a magnificent deflation of smugness. Pal, you've added ten years to my life! A poet with a straight left and a right hook - delicious! Delicious! You're my guest from now on - forever and a day - even unto eternity!

question: Thanks, but Miss Dawson and I are going out to see the sights.
answer: Fine, fine. Swell, You just showed me a sight lovely to behold, and I'd like to reciprocate. Listen, you hop aboard my magic carpet

question: I'd kind of like to see Grant's Tomb - and the Statue of Liberty.
answer: Well, you'll not only see those, but before the evening's half through, you'll be leaning against the Leaning Tower of Pisa - you'll mount Mt. Everest. I'll show you the Pyramids and all the little Pyramiddes, leaping from sphinx to sphinx. Pal, how would you like to go on a real, old-fashioned binge? Yes. I mean the real McCoy. Listen, you play saloon with me, and I'll introduce you to every wit, every nit-wit, and every half-wit in New York. We'll go on a twister that'll make Omar the soused philosopher of Persia look like an anemic on a goat's milk diet. Fun? Say, listen, I'll take you on a bender that will live in your memory as a thing of beauty and joy forever.

question: Yes, I guess we will.
answer: Cinderella Man! That's sensational, Babe! Sensational!

question: It took some high-powered acting, believe me.
answer: Did it?

question: I was the world's sweetest ingenue.
answer: Is he really that big a sap?

question: He's the original. There are no carbon copies of that one.
answer: Cinderella Man! Babe, you stuck a tag on that hick that'll stick to him the rest of his life. Can you imagine Cobb's face when he reads this?

question: If we could sell tickets, we'd make a fortune.
answer: How'd you get the picture?

question: Had the boys follow us.
answer: Marvelous!

question: I don't know. I had to duck to get the story out. He was so far along he never even missed me.
answer: When're you going to see him again?

question: Tonight, maybe. I even moved into Mabel Dawson's apartment - in case old snoopy Cobb might start looking around.
answer: Sure.

question: Mr. Deeds - Mr. Deeds, sir - you really must get up. It's late! Yes, sir.
answer: I just wanted to make sure.

question: If you'll permit me to say so, sir, you were out on quite a bender last night, sir.
answer: Bender? You're wrong, Walter. We started out to a binge but we never got to it. What's that?

question: A Prairie Oyster, sir. Yes, sir. It makes the head feel smaller. Miss Dawson, sir? No, sir. No Miss Dawson has called, sir.
answer: She was a lady in distress. She wouldn't let me help her. Got a lot of pride. I like that.

question: Oh, I do too, sir.
answer: I'd better call her up and apologize. I don't remember taking her home last night.

question: I'd venture to say, sir, you don't remember much of anything that happened last night, sir.
answer: What do you mean? I remember everything! Hand me my pants - I wrote her phone number on a piece of paper.

question: You have no pants, sir. You came home last night - without them. As a matter of fact, you came home without any clothes. You were in your - uh - shorts. Yes, sir.
answer: Oh, don't be silly, Walter. I couldn't walk around in the streets without any clothes. I'd be arrested.

question: That's what the two policemn said, sir.
answer: What two policemen?

question: The ones who brought you home, sir. They said you and another gentleman kept walking up and down the streets, shouting
answer: Listen, Walter, if a man named Morrow calls up, tell him I'm not in. He may be a great author, but I think he's crazy. The man's crazy, Walter.

question: Yes, sir. By the way, did you But how'll I put on the slipper, sir?
answer: Looking for?

question: Arthur! Who's Arthur?
answer: He's the shipping clerk at the Tallow Works. Wants a $2 raise - or he'll quit. Oh, they insisted on following me.

question: Are those stories true?
answer: I don't remember. "Cinderella Man!" What do they mean by that?

question: They'd call you anything if you gave them half a chance. They've got you down as a sap.
answer: Sometimes it's the only solution.

question: Not editors. Take my word for it. Not editors!
answer: If they're going to poke fun at me, I'm going to

question: That's my job. I'll take care of that. I'll keep that stuff out of the papers - if you'll help me. But I can't do anything if you go around talking to people. Will you promise me to be careful from now on?
answer: Yes, I guess I'll have to. Cobb's right. I mustn't talk to anybody.

question: Got any news
answer: Sure. I met you. Oh, that - well, we had another meeting. I told them I'd go on being Chairman if

question: Yes, I know.
answer: I told 'em I'd play along with them if they lowered their prices - and cut down expenses - and broadcast.

question: What did they say?
answer: Gosh, you look pretty tonight.

question: What did they say?
answer: Huh? Oh. They said I was crazy. Said I wanted to run it like a grocery store.

question: What are they going to do?
answer: Have you seen the papers?

question: Uh-huh.
answer: That's what I like about you. You think about a man's feelings. I'd like to go down to that newspaper and punch the fellow in the nose that's writing that stuff "Cinderella Man!" I guess pretty soon everybody will be calling me "Cinderella Man."

question: Would you like to walk the rest of the way? It's so nice out.
answer: Yes.

question: Who cares what you were saying to your wife?
answer: Yes?

question: Those people have been in to see me every day this week. They keep insisting they should have some nuisance value.
answer: Nuisance value?

question: There's Times Square.
answer: You can almost spit on it, can't you?

question: Why don't you try? You're worried about those articles they're writing about you, aren't you?
answer: I'm not worrying any more. I suppose they'll go on writing them till they get tired. You don't believe all that stuff, do you?

question: Oh, they just do it to sell the newspapers, you know.
answer: Yeah, I guess so. What puzzles me is why people seem to get so much pleasure out of hurting each other. Why don't they try liking each other once in a while?

question: Shall we go?
answer: Yeah. Anyway, there aren't any photographers around.

question: You know, you said something to me when you first met me that I've thought about a great deal.
answer: What's that?

question: You said I was a lady in distress.
answer: Oh, that

question: What did you mean by that?
answer: Nothing Have you got a - are you - uh - engaged or anything?

question: No. Are you?
answer: No.

question: You don't go out with girls very much, do you?
answer: I haven't.

question: Why not?
answer: Oh, I don't know.

question: You must have met a lot of swell society girls since you've been here. Don't you like them?
answer: I haven't met anybody here that I like, particularly. They all seem to have the St. Vitus Dance. I'd rather have Mandrake Falls.

question: I'm from a small town too, you know. Probably as small as Mandrake Falls. Ah, it's a beautiful little town, too. A row of poplar trees right along Main Street. Always smelled as if it just had a bath. I've often thought about going back.
answer: You have?

question: Oh, yes. I used to have a lot of fun there when I was a little girl. I used to love to go fishing with my father. That's funny. He was a lot like you, my father was. Talked like you, too. Sometimes he'd let me hold the line while he smoked - and we'd just sit there for hours. And after awhile, for no reason, I'd go over and kiss him and sit in his lap. He never said very much but once I remember him saying
answer: He sounds like a person worth while knowing. He did? I play the tuba

question: Yeah, I know.
answer: What did he play?

question: The drums. He taught me to play some.
answer: He did?

question: Yes. I can do "Swanee River." Would you like to hear me? Oh, I suppose you could do better.
answer: Sure. I can sing "Humoresque."

question: "Humoresque"? I'll bet you don't even know how it goes.
answer: Sure. Look! You sing it over again, and I'll do "Humoresque" with you.

question: Hello.
answer: I wanted to thank you again for going out with me.

question: Well, that's very nice. Thank you.
answer: You know what I've been doing since I got home? Been working on a poem. Maybe I'll have it finished next time I see you.

question: Good night. Mabel, that guy's either the dumbest, the stupidest, the most imbecilic idiot in the world - or he's the grandest thing alive. I can't make him out. I'm crucifying him.
answer: People have been crucified before.

question: Why? Why do we have to do it?
answer: You started out to be a successful newspaper woman, didn't you?

question: Yeah, then what? Here's a guy that's wholesome and fresh. To us he looks like a freak. You know what he told me tonight? He said when he gets married he wants to carry his bride over the threshold in his arms.
answer: The guy's balmy.

question: Is he? Yeah, I thought so, too. I tried to laugh, but I couldn't. It stuck in my throat.
answer: Aw, cut it out, will you? You'll get me thinking about Charlie again.

question: He's got goodness, Mabel. Do you know what that is?
answer: Huh?

question: I beg pardon, sir. I beg pardon, sir. Madame Pomponi is on the telephone, sir.
answer: Who?

question: Madame Pomponi. She says everything is all set for the reception.
answer: What do you mean by coming in here when I'm playing?

question: But she's on the telephone
answer: Get out. Stop! Hey, did you hear that?

question: What, sir?
answer: You try it.

question: Hello.
answer: Hello, Mary. I waited in the park for you over an hour. I thought maybe you'd forgotten.

question: Mabel in b.g. I didn't think you could come with the party and everything.
answer: Oh, I wouldn't let them stop me from seeing you. So I threw them out!

question: The reason why I wanted to take a walk, Mary, is 'cause I wanted to talk to you.
answer: Let's just walk, okay?

question: All right. Mary, I'm going home.
answer: Are you? When?

question: In a day or so, I think.
answer: I don't blame you.

question: A man ought to know where he fits in. I just don't fit in around here. I once had an idea I could do something with the money, but they kept me so busy here, I haven't had time to figure it out. I guess I'll wait till I get back home. Do you mind if I talk to you, Mary? You don't have to pay any attention to me.
answer: No, I don't mind.

question: All my life, I've wanted somebody to talk to. Back in Mandrake Falls, I always used to talk to a girl.
answer: A girl?

question: Oh, an imaginary one. I used to hike a lot through the woods and I'd always take this girl Well, here we are again.
answer: Yes, here we are again. Goodbye, darling. Don't let anybody hurt you again - ever. They can't anyway. You're much too real. You go back to Mandrake Falls. That's where you belong - goodbye!

question: Mary You know the poem I told you about? It's finished. Would you like to read it? It's to you.
answer: "I tramped the earth with hopeless beat - Searching in vain for a glimpse of you. Then heaven thrust you at my very feet, A lovely angel - too lovely to woo." "My dream has been answered, but my life's just as bleak, Oh, darling!

question: "I tramped the earth with hopeless beat - Searching in vain for a glimpse of you. Then heaven thrust you at my very feet, A lovely angel - too lovely to woo." "My dream has been answered, but my life's just as bleak, Oh, darling!
answer: Stop it, Babe! Stop it! What do you mean, you're quitting! You might as well tell me I'm quitting. What's bothering you, huh? Proposed to you! You mean he asked you to marry him?

question: Yes. Print one line of that, and I'll blow your place up!
answer: Sorry, Babe. Sorry. It would have made a swell story. I just got carried away. That's too bad. So he proposed to you, huh? Well, I'll be That's tough, Babe. Tell him you're Babe Bennett? Tell him you've been making a stooge out of him?

question: I'm having lunch with him today. He expects an answer. It's going to be pretty.
answer: You're crazy! You can't do that!

question: He'll probably kick me right down the stairs. I only hope he does.
answer: I'll put you on another job. You need never see him again, eh?

question: That's the rub.
answer: Oh, as bad as that, huh?

question: How's it going? Okay?
answer: Yes, quite all right. Thank you, sir.

question: Fourteen carat?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Is that the best you've got?
answer: Oh, yes sir. Stuff, sir?

question: That goo. That stuff that tastes like soap.
answer: Oh, yes, sir. Here it is, sir. The pate de fois gras, sir.

question: Yeah, that's fine. Have a lot of it because she likes it.
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Now you got the idea. Fine.
answer: Me sir?

question: Yes. Yes. You're too tall. Slink lower, will you? More. Now forward.
answer: I wish you luck, sir.

question: Thank you. Now don't touch a thing. Leave everything as it is.
answer: Yes, sir. What is it, sir? Anything happened3

question: Anything happened? I've got to get dressed! I can't meet her like this!
answer: But she isn't due for an hour, sir.

question: An hour? What's an hour! You know how time flies, Walter. My tie? Get it.
answer: Yes, sir. Very good, sir. Here it is right here, sir. There, sir.

question: You can't come up here!
answer: What's going on here?

question: There he is! I just wanted to get a look at him. There you are! I just wanted to see what kind of a man you were!
answer: Come on! Take him out of here!

question: Let me go! Let me alone!
answer: No!

question: Yeah - that's all that's worrying you. What do I want? A chance to feed a wife and kids! I'm a farmer. A job! That's what I want!
answer: A farmer, eh! You're a moocher, that's what you are! I wouldn't believe you or anybody else on a stack of bibles! You're a moocher like all the rest of them around here, so get out of here!

question: We have very little time. He's ordered me to turn everything over to him immediately. We have to work fast before he disposes of every penny.
answer: See! I told you something could be done. I knew it all the time. Sign it, dear. Oh, don't be so squeamish.

question: There are millions involved. After all, you have your legal rights. You're his only living relatives.
answer: That's your agreement with Mr. Cedar, if we win.

question: You see, my end is going to be rather expensive. I have a lot of important people to take care of. I have the legal machinery all set and ready to go. I've been working on nothing else for the last week. You say the word, and we'll stop this yokel dead in his tracks.
answer: Sign it!

question: All set.
answer: Okay, then. Go to it.

question: Yeah?
answer: Find out who wrote those newspaper articles and subpoena them right away.

question: What is your name?
answer: Christian Svenson.

question: Farmer?
answer: Yes, ma'am.

question: Where is your farm?
answer: South Dakota north.

question: South Dakota - north?
answer: South Dakota - but on the top.

question: Oh. Oh!
answer: What about your knocking off for lunch?

question: Not hungry. I want to get through this work in a hurry, and then I want to go home. What price did you get on those trucks?
answer: Come on, come on. What are you trying to do, kid? Keel over? You haven't been out of this house in two weeks.

question: Good. Well, that doesn't make 'em any less hungry.
answer: Okay, Santa Claus. 2000 lunches.

question: Okay, Santa Claus. 2000 lunches.
answer: Sheriff's office. A warrant for your arrest. You'll have to come along with us.

question: What's up? What do you mugs want?
answer: I don't know nothing, buddy. All I know is the Sheriff gives me an insanity warrant to execute.

question: Insanity! Who's says he's insane? Oh, somebody got panic-stricken about his giving his dough away, eh?
answer: To the County Hospital.

question: I have before me a series of articles written by a newspaper woman who was an eye-witness to his conduct ever since he came to New York.
answer: She tells how, in the midst of a normal conversation, he would suddenly begin playing his tuba. She tells of his attacks upon several of our eminent writers - for no apparent reason. In fact, there are many instances not recorded in these articles in which Mr. Deeds satisfied an unnatural desire to smash people up without provocation. I, myself, unable to keep pace with his mental quirks, and constantly fearful of assault, turned down an opportunity to represent him as his attorney. This newspaper woman, whom we have subpoenaed to testify, tells how he tied up traffic for an hour feeding doughnuts to a poor horse. And by his own statement, waiting for that horse to ask for a cup of coffee. We have photographs to substantiate this little episode, and other photographs showing Mr. Deeds jumping upon a fire engine. This scarcely sounds like the action of a man in whom the disposition of twenty million dollars may safely be entrusted. This writer of these articles - a woman whose intelligence and integrity in the newspaper world is unquestioned - held him in such contempt that she quite aptly named him "The Cinderella Man."

question: We have witnesses here from Mandrake Falls, his own home town, who will tell of his conduct throughout his lifetime, proving that his derangement is neither recent nor a temporary one.
answer: We have others who will tell of his unusual behavior when he invited the great leaders of the musical world to his home, and then proceeded to forcibly eject them. Only recently when he was in the County Hospital for observation, he not only refused to be examined by these gentlemen, the state psychiatrists, but he actually made a violent attack upon them. In these times, with the country incapacitated by economic ailments, and endangered with an undercurrent of social unrest, the promulgation of such a weird, fantastic and impractical plan as contemplated by the defendant, is capable of fomenting a disturbance from which the country may not soon recover. It is our duty to stop it! Our government is fully aware of its difficulties and can pull itself out of its economic rut without the assistance of Mr. Deeds, or any other crackpot.

question: Miss Bennett, please. Raise your right hand, please. Do you solemnly swear the testimony you may give before this court to be the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth, so help you God?
answer: I do.

question: State your right name, please.
answer: Louise Bennett.

question: Were you given an assignment to follow the activities of Longfellow Deeds?
answer: Yes.

question: Did you subsequently write a series of articles about him?
answer: Yes! Yes!

question: Were you present when all these things took place?
answer: Yes!

question: Are they true!
answer: NO!!

question: But they did take place?
answer: They're colored! Just to make him look silly!

question: And you saw them happen?
answer: Yes, but I

question: Your Honor, I wish to call your attention to these exhibits. Mr. Davis, do you recognize these reproductions?
answer: Sure, they're good enlargements. Where'd you have them made?

question: Did you make the originals of them?
answer: Sure. I took the originals. Taking pictures is my business. I photograph a lot of nuts.

question: He must be made to defend himself before you arrive at a decision.
answer: Very well. Take the stand.

question: Oh, thank you!
answer: Let her speak.

question: I know why he won't defend himself! That has a bearing on the case, hasn't it? He's been hurt! He's been hurt by everybody's he met since he came here, principally by me. He's been the victim of every conniving crook in town. The newspapers pounced on him - made him a target for their feeble humor. I was smarter than the rest of them! I got closer to him so I could laugh louder. Why shouldn't he keep quiet? Every time he said anything it was twisted around to sound imbecilic. He can thank me for it! I handed the gang a grand laugh. This is a fitting climax to my sense of humor.
answer: But Your Honor - this is preposterous!

question: Certainly I wrote those articles. I was going to get a raise - and a month's vacation! But I stopped writing them when I found out what he was all about! When I realized how real he was.
answer: Your Honor, this is absurd. The woman's obviously in love with him.

question: What's that got to do with it?
answer: Your Honor, her testimony is of no value. Why shouldn't she defend him? It's a tribute to American womanhood - the instinct to protect the weak. I'm not saying that nobody likes the boy. I cherish a fond affection for him myself. But that doesn't mean to say

question: Your Honor I'd like to get in my two cents' worth.
answer: Take the stand! Proceed.

question: Well, I don't know where to begin. There's been so many things said about me that I About my playing the tuba. Seems like a lot of fuss has been made about that. If a man's crazy just 'cause he plays the tuba, then somebody better look into it, 'cause there are a lot of tuba players running around loose. Of course, I don't see any harm in it. I play mine whenever I want to concentrate. That may sound funny to some people - but everybody does something silly when they're thinking. For instance, the Judge here is an O-filler . . .
answer: A what?
